verses.text: He entered Jericho and was passing through.
verses.comment: Jericho, a significant biblical city, is a place of both destruction and restoration. Jesus' passing through symbolizes both judgment and mercy.

verses.text: And behold, there was a man named Zacchaeus. He was a chief tax collector and was wealthy.
verses.comment: Tax collectors were despised by the Jews for colluding with Rome and being seen as sinners. Zacchaeus' wealth highlights his social status and the scandal of Jesus reaching out to him.

verses.text: He was trying to see who Jesus was, but because of the crowd he could not, for he was short in stature.
verses.comment: Zacchaeus’ physical limitation echoes deeper spiritual longing; he overcomes obstacles to see the Lord, showing a desire for grace.

verses.text: So he ran ahead and climbed up into a sycamore tree to see Him, because Jesus was about to pass that way.
verses.comment: His action signifies humility and persistence in seeking Christ—key aspects of genuine conversion.

verses.text: When Jesus came to the place, He looked up and said to him, 'Zacchaeus, hurry and come down, for today I must stay at your house.'
verses.comment: Jesus calls Zacchaeus by name, manifesting divine knowledge and initiative. 'Must stay' signals Jesus' authority and the necessity of Zacchaeus’ encounter with grace.

verses.text: So he hurried down and received Him joyfully.
verses.comment: Reception with joy mirrors encounters with Christ throughout Scripture (Acts 16:34); it’s both a spiritual and literal acceptance.

verses.text: And when they saw it, they all grumbled, saying, 'He has gone in to be the guest of a man who is a sinner.'
verses.comment: The grumbling crowd reflects human reluctance to accept divine mercy for outcasts; Christ’s mission is to sinners (Luke 5:32).

verses.text: Zacchaeus stood and said to the Lord, 'Look, Lord, I give half of my possessions to the poor, and if I have cheated anyone of anything, I repay four times as much.'
verses.comment: His repentance is concrete, aligning with both the law (restitution) and charity. Faith is demonstrated by works (see James 2:17).

verses.text: Jesus said to him, 'Today salvation has come to this house, because he too is a son of Abraham.'
verses.comment: Salvation is personal and communal; Zacchaeus’ faith restores him to the people of God. The phrase “son of Abraham” highlights fulfillment of covenant promises.

verses.text: For the Son of Man came to seek and to save the lost.'
verses.comment: 'Son of Man' invokes Daniel 7:13–14, underscoring Jesus' divinity and messianic role. The mission to save the lost encapsulates Christ’s ministry.

verses.text: As they listened to these things, He went on to tell a parable because He was near Jerusalem, and because they supposed that the kingdom of God was going to appear immediately.
verses.comment: Jesus corrects misunderstandings about the timing and nature of God’s kingdom; it is both present and future.

verses.text: He said therefore, 'A nobleman went into a distant country to receive a kingdom for himself and then return.
verses.comment: The nobleman is a Christ-figure; the parable draws from familiar situations (Herod Archelaus’ journey to Rome for kingship).

verses.text: He called ten of his servants, gave them ten minas, and said to them, ‘Engage in business until I come.’
verses.comment: The ‘minas’ parable emphasizes stewardship and faithfulness during Christ’s physical absence.

verses.text: But his citizens hated him and sent a delegation after him, saying, ‘We do not want this man to rule over us.’
verses.comment: Resistance to the nobleman parallels Israel’s historic rejection of God’s chosen leaders (cf. 1 Sam 8:7).

verses.text: When he returned, having received the kingdom, he ordered those servants to whom he had given the money to be called to him, that he might know what they had gained by doing business.
verses.comment: Christ’s return will bring judgment on the faithfulness of His followers (cf. Rom 14:12).

verses.text: The first came before him, saying, ‘Lord, your mina has made ten more minas.’
verses.comment: A faithful servant multiplies what is entrusted to him—spiritual and material fruitfulness is expected.

verses.text: He said to him, ‘Well done, good servant. Because you have been faithful in very little, you shall have authority over ten cities.’
verses.comment: Earthly faithfulness is rewarded in the coming kingdom; note the association of works with reward.

verses.text: The second came, saying, ‘Lord, your mina has made five minas.’
verses.comment: Servants’ varying results highlight diverse gifts and opportunities within the community of believers.

verses.text: He said to him as well, ‘And you are to be over five cities.’
verses.comment: Each receives rewards proportionate to their fruitful labor in the Master’s service.

verses.text: Then another came, saying, ‘Lord, here is your mina, which I kept laid away in a cloth.’
verses.comment: The inactive servant fails to use the entrusted gift; a warning against spiritual complacency.

verses.text: ‘For I was afraid of you, because you are a severe man. You take what you did not deposit, and reap what you did not sow.’
verses.comment: This view of the master distorts the reality of divine justice and grace.

verses.text: He said to him, ‘I will judge you by your own words, you wicked servant! You knew that I was a severe man, taking what I did not deposit and reaping what I did not sow?
verses.comment: Judgment is just, and is based on our choices; the unresponsive to grace is held accountable.

verses.text: Then why did you not put my money in the bank, and at my coming I might have collected it with interest?’
verses.comment: Even minimal use of the gifts entrusted would have been acceptable; God expects our participation.

verses.text: And he said to those who stood by, ‘Take the mina from him, and give it to the one who has ten minas.’
verses.comment: Grace—when refused—is given to those who respond. This echoes spiritual realities of losing gifts through negligence.

verses.text: And they said to him, ‘Lord, he already has ten minas!’
verses.comment: The Master’s distribution is based on faithful stewardship, not mere equality.

verses.text: ‘I tell you, that to everyone who has, more will be given. But from the one who does not have, even what he has will be taken away.
verses.comment: God rewards faithfulness richly; this principle runs throughout Scripture.

verses.text: But as for these enemies of mine, who did not want me to reign over them, bring them here and slaughter them before me.’”
verses.comment: Harsh judgment against rejection of the true King; hints at final judgment (see Rev. 20:15).

verses.text: And after saying these things, He went on ahead, going up to Jerusalem.
verses.comment: The decisive journey to Jerusalem begins; Jesus sets his face toward his Passion.

verses.text: When He drew near to Bethphage and Bethany, at the hill called the Mount of Olives, He sent two of His disciples,
verses.comment: The Mount of Olives is associated with messianic expectation and final redemption.

verses.text: saying, “Go into the village ahead of you; and as you enter it, you will find a colt tied on which no one has ever sat. Untie it and bring it here.
verses.comment: Jesus deliberately fulfills prophecy concerning the Messiah’s entry (cf. Zech 9:9).

verses.text: If anyone asks you, ‘Why are you untying it?’ you shall say, ‘The Lord has need of it.’”
verses.comment: ‘The Lord has need’—Jesus exercises divine authority; a subtle claim to divinity.

verses.text: So those who were sent went away and found it just as He had told them.
verses.comment: Jesus’ foreknowledge and instructions fulfill His prophetic role.

verses.text: And as they were untying the colt, its owners said to them, “Why are you untying the colt?”
verses.comment: The owners’ inquiry enables the disciples to identify their purpose as in verse 31.

verses.text: They said, “The Lord has need of it.”
verses.comment: Using the title 'Lord' for Jesus suggests His sovereignty and messianic role.

verses.text: And they brought it to Jesus, and throwing their cloaks on the colt, they set Jesus on it.
verses.comment: Laying cloaks is a gesture of honor, recognizing Jesus as King.

verses.text: As He went along, they spread their cloaks on the road.
verses.comment: Further emphasizes royal entry, recalling traditional acts honoring a new king.

verses.text: As He approached the descent from the Mount of Olives, the whole multitude of disciples began to rejoice and praise God with a loud voice for all the mighty works they had seen,
verses.comment: The multitude’s praise fulfills prophetic expectation of the Messiah’s coming.

verses.text: saying, “Blessed is the King who comes in the name of the Lord! Peace in heaven and glory in the highest!”
verses.comment: Echoes Psalm 118 and angels’ praise at Jesus’ birth; confirms Jesus’ royal and divine identity.

verses.text: Some of the Pharisees from the crowd said to Him, “Teacher, rebuke your disciples.”
verses.comment: The Pharisees’ request shows their rejection of His Messiahship.

verses.text: He answered, “I tell you, if these were silent, the stones would cry out.”
verses.comment: Creation itself testifies to Christ’s kingship; this is a claim to divine authority.

verses.text: As He drew near and saw the city, He wept over it,
verses.comment: Jesus’ tears reveal God’s compassion for His people and the consequences of rejecting Him.

verses.text: saying, “If you, even you, had known on this day the things that make for peace! But now they are hidden from your eyes.
verses.comment: Spiritual blindness results from persistent unbelief; echoes the prophets.

verses.text: For the days will come upon you, when your enemies will build a barricade around you and surround you and hem you in on every side,
verses.comment: Jesus predicts Jerusalem’s destruction in 70 AD, a direct result of rejecting His visitation.

verses.text: and will level you to the ground, you and your children within you. And they will not leave one stone upon another in you, because you did not recognize the time of your visitation.”
verses.comment: Failure to discern God’s visitation leads to judgment. Note fulfillment of prophecy in Daniel and Lamentations.

verses.text: And He entered the temple and began to drive out those who sold,
verses.comment: Jesus purifies the temple, authoritatively exercising judgment in the house of God—foreshadowing the ongoing sanctification of the Church.

verses.text: saying to them, “It is written, ‘My house shall be a house of prayer,’ but you have made it a den of robbers.”
verses.comment: Cleansing the temple fulfills prophecy and affirms the sanctity of worship. The temple, in New Testament theology, is both Christ’s body and the gathered believers.

verses.text: And He was teaching daily in the temple. The chief priests and the scribes and the leaders of the people were seeking to destroy Him,
verses.comment: Opposition is mounting from religious leaders. Jesus’ authority in teaching and judgment is contrasted with their self-interest.

verses.text: but they did not find anything they could do, for all the people were hanging on His words.
verses.comment: The people’s attraction to Jesus’ teaching points toward the future gathering of believers that clings to the apostolic faith.
